title: DataStax Presents: Cloud Databases 201 with Jonathan Ellis
description:
From DataStax Developer Day in Dallas on 10/25/2018, DataStax co-founder and CTO Jonathan Ellis gives an overview of the similarities and difference of the main cloud distributed databases: Apache Cassandra / DataStax Enterprise, Amazon’s DynamoDB, Microsoft Azure Cosmos DB, and Google Cloud Spanner DB. Jonathan provides a comparison of performance and cost characteristics of these databases, including some interesting results from benchmarking DSE performance when using a JVM with the Z Garbage Collector (ZGC).

Highlights
0:00 - This talk focuses on operational cloud databases that scale out: Apache Cassandra / DataStax Enterprise, Amazon DynamoDB, Microsoft Azure Cosmos DB, and Google Cloud Spanner DB
1:10 - There are a few things all of these databases agree on: 
1:30 - 1) Eventual consistency is useful
4:30 - 2) Automatic partitioning doesn’t work
6:58 - 3) SQL is a pretty ok query language
8:42 - Something not everyone agrees on: Schema is good
13:01 - Practical considerations and head to head comparisons: 1) DSE vs. Cosmos DB Cassandra API in performance and pricing
17:03 - Aside on DSE benchmark with the Z Garbage Collector (ZGC) 
18:50 - 2) Can’t benchmark DynamoDB vs DSE due to lack of CQL/SQL support, but it’s 20% more expensive than Cosmos with less features
19:15 - 3) a comparison of Spanner with Kudu (similar architecture to Cassandra). Since Spanner supports ACID, Kudu demonstrates more throughput
20:23 - The importance of your database choice in avoiding lock-in and supporting Hybrid Cloud and multi-cloud architectures
22:25 - DataStax Managed Cloud, recommendations and conclusions


ABOUT DATASTAX ENTERPRISE 6
DataStax  powers  the  Right-Now  Enterprise  with  the  always-on,  distributed  cloud  database  built  on  Apache  Cassandra™  and designed for hybrid cloud. DataStax Enterprise 6 (DSE 6) includes industry-leading performance, self-driving operational simplicity, and robust analytics.

Learn more at http://www.datastax.com/products/datastax

saying on the right here is that this is a time series schema where we have a bunch we have a million sensors and they're all generating data points that have a timestamp associated with them and a data payload and so that's the that's the schema that we're working with so we did three scenarios we've benchmarked three scenarios one where we're varying the percentage of Rights vs. reads so the first one is 10% writes 90% reads and then bottom one is the inverse and then the middle ones 50/50 and so we priced that out and we actually scaled up the cluster to the cosmos to be thinks of this in terms of request units you know how how much is it gonna cost for a cosmos DB database to match the performance of a 5 node DSE cluster in running in Microsoft Azure so that's that's what we did here so we we found that the cosmos to be was going to be between 2.5 and almost 10 times as expensive to get that performance so yeah there's definitely a level of convenience there where cosmos DB is handling all the operations but you're definitely paying for it as well the other thing we looked at was okay that's the throughput but what is the what does the latency look like so what we did here is i'll point out that on the left this is a log scale graph so every every line there from we're going an order of magnitude from ten to one hundred and two thousand and so here then at the bottom this is what Cosmos DB publishes as their SLA and they say we're gonna guarantee that 99% of operations finish in less than this amount and so what we did was so we took we took the level of throughput that we're benchmarking here and we said what does the latency look like when we start with 20% of that throughput and go up to eighty percent of it and so you can see that what we have here is the the purple and the teal these are DC's lines and then you've got the orange and the slightly different orange the header Cosmos DB lines and I apologize I'm for anyone in the audience who's colorblind like me I apologize those are probably bad colors to choose but you can see that that we're blowing way past the SLA the bad news for for data stacks fans is data sex isn't doing a whole lot better it's a little bit lower but not a whole lot better and in fact Kosmos DB is actually doing a lot better on the read latency in particular before we hit that 80% level when it just it just kind of falls apart a little bit so so that's that's the latency story but this is the the rest of the latency story so we also benchmarked it with the new zgc garbage collector that's a that's out in java 11 and so this these are the new DSC numbers with with java 11 you can see that we're doing again this is log scale so we're doing roughly an order of magnitude almost two orders of magnitude better on the 99th percentile and doing significantly better on not just the eighty eighty percent but also all the other levels of workload that we're throwing at it if you're not familiar with with Java garbage collection algorithms great talk introducing GGC from the author that you can google but the short version is that it optimizes for much shorter pauses at the expense of using a little more CPU so so what that what this graph tells us is that most of the 99th percentile pauses that you get with DSC today are the result of the Java garbage collector and not the result of DHC itself and when you address that with a better garbage collector and by the way Azul zine is another option besides GGC and they'll be happy to sell that to you today so you can you can make those Layton sees get much better with DSA one more point about about the the latency from that we saw with cosmos TB we it wasn't really a normal curve so it wasn't really like you here's the most common latency and then you've got your kind of gets less common as you get away from that most common one it's really more of a bimodal where you either have you know right around meeting the SLA of around 10 or you have a at about a thousand so those are those are definitely the most common you get a couple outliers but it was more of a bimodal distribution which was a little surprising so DynamoDB we can't benchmark it directly there's no Cassandra API but if we go by what their documents documentation suggests and their pricing that they published it's about 20% more expensive than cosmo's TB and it's significantly weaker in terms of the the data model which again is a key value based and the other features that it provides spanner we I don't have a head-to-head comparison with Cassandra but I do have a comparison that someone from cloud era did against database called kudu and the interesting thing about this is cooter shares a lot of architectural things in common with Cassandra so I would expect that on the load throughput in particular that that Cassandra would do similarly to kudu - you know 50 to 100 percent better and I would expect Cassandra to do significantly better on the reads because kudu is optimized for analytical scans rather than the point queries that this benchmark is testing but this is this is what what they found which is that spanner just really again are you kind of glossed over it earlier but spanner is optimized for all acid all the time and that means that in a distributed system you give up a lot of performance to get that and and that's that's visible here so the last thing I want to point out is that when you're talking about a cloud database you know write once run anywhere that was Java's tagline for a while and I think it's an important thing to think about when you're talking about where am I going to just deploy my application and what infrastructure isn't going to run on so you've got a bunch of industry analysts saying that there's an increasing awareness that hybrid cloud is more and more important and it's not enough to just you know have a database that runs on one cloud and nowhere else Gardner had a useful way of thinking about hybrid cloud that they divided it into four categories where the first one is architecture spanning where you actually have this is diagram is trying to say that I have a single database that's spanning from an on-premises deployment and into the cloud and and Cassandra is one of the few databases that can do that but then the other ones are variations on I have some data on premise and some data in the cloud and they don't necessarily need to replicate to each other but it's good to have a common interface so that I'm not you know I don't have to write my application one way on-premise and a different way for the cloud and this is what data stacks is seeing as well we're seeing roughly 63 percent of our customers running applications in the cloud and those are a subset of the hundred percent that have applications running on premise as well so yeah we agree that this is this is the future so my takeaway from that is you know I I wouldn't want to be locked into a database that only runs on one cloud I want the flexibility to deploy that on-premise I want the flexibility to know if my company acquires someone who's using a different cloud I want to be able to have a data layer that I can have in common between those so a data stacks besides running new selling licenses that you can run on premises we also have data stacks manage cloud will run data stacks for you on the cloud of your choice and so my recommendations are first that I would never recommend dynamodb the feature set is just too limiting the data model is is not as productive you will not write your application as fast and spanner is just too slow and too expensive for what you get now that the price of acid in a distributed system is very high Kosmos to be I've got a lot of respect for what they built it's a good system it does get expensive as you scale it and then of course my bias I'm the founder of data stacks but you know I think that I think I've made a pretty good case for why data stacks Enterprise sets makes a good set of trade-offs as a cloud database I let my final thought I don't have time for questions this morning but feel free to catch me around in the halls but we are hiring if you like thinking about distributed systems then reach out unless your data stacks customer in which case forget I said anything your boss will be upset with me but if you're not a data stacks customer and this kind of stuff excites you then let's talk thank you [Applause]
